utterance.speaker: Melanie
utterance.content: Why are you late?

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: You’re not going to like the answer.

utterance.speaker: Melanie
utterance.content: I already know the answer.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: I missed the bus.

utterance.speaker: Melanie
utterance.content: I don’t doubt it, no bus stops near Brad’s. You spent the night, the alarm didn’t work. Or maybe it did.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: I didn’t sleep with him.

utterance.speaker: Melanie
utterance.content: Girl, there’s...

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: I missed the bus!

utterance.speaker: Melanie
utterance.content: There’s something either very wrong with you, or there’s something very wrong with him.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: There’s nothing wrong with him.

utterance.speaker: Melanie
utterance.content: Please tell me you know that for a fact.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Melanie, I gotta go.

utterance.speaker: Melanie
utterance.content: You’re lying aren’t you?

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: I wouldn’t lie to you. Good morning guys!

utterance.speaker: Class
utterance.content: Good morning Miss Rebecca!

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Everybody’s in their seats?

utterance.speaker: Class
utterance.content: Yes!

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Ok, Sidney, why don’t you tell us what you did this weekend. Come on, Sidney, we know you’re not shy.

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: How come we always have to tell you what we did, and you never tell us what you did?

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Ok, I had a really great weekend, but you can’t tell Miss Melanie, ok?

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: What did you do?

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: I made a new friend. It’s so much fun to make new friends, isn’t it?

utterance.speaker: Class
utterance.content: Yeah, Yes, etc.

utterance.speaker: Girl 2
utterance.content: Did you tell you mom and dad about your new friend?

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Absolutely! You should never keep anything from your parents. And I told them

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Wh..

utterance.speaker: Class
utterance.content: C, A, T, H

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: “The.”

utterance.speaker: Boy
utterance.content: We know that word, “the.”

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: 29 year old female, first seizure one month ago, lost the ability to speak. Babbled like a baby. Present deterioration of mental status.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: See that? They all assume I’m a patient because of this cane.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So put on a white coat like the rest of us.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t want them to think I’m a doctor.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You see where the administration might have a problem with that attitude.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: People don’t want a sick doctor.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Fair enough. I don’t like healthy patients. The 29 year old female…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The one who can’t talk, I liked that part.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She’s my cousin.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And your cousin doesn’t like the diagnosis. I wouldn’t either. Brain tumor, she’s gonna die, boring.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No wonder you’re such a renowned diagnostician. You don’t need to actually know anything to figure out what’s wrong.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re the oncologist; I’m just a lowly infectious disease guy.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hah, yes, just a simple country doctor. Brain tumors at her age are highly unlikely.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s 29. Whatever she’s got is highly unlikely.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Protein markers for the three most prevalent brain cancers came up negative.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s an HMO lab; you might as well have sent it to a high school kid with a chemistry set.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No family history.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I thought your uncle died of cancer.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Other side. No environmental factors.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That you know of.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And she’s not responding to radiation treatment.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: None of which is even close to dispositive. All it does is raise one question. Your cousin goes to an HMO?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Come on! Why leave all the fun for the coroner? What’s the point of putting together a team if you’re not going to use them? You’ve got three overqualified doctors working for you. Getting bored.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s a lesion.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And the big green thing in the middle of the bigger blue thing on a map is an island. I was hoping for something a bit more creative.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Shouldn’t we be speaking to the patient before we start diagnosing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is she a doctor?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, but…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Everybody lies.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Dr. House doesn’t like dealing with patients.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Isn’t treating patients why we became doctors?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, treating illnesses is why we became doctors, treating patients is what makes most doctors miserable.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So you’re trying to eliminate the humanity from the practice of medicine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If we don’t talk to them they can’t lie to us, and we can’t lie to them. Humanity is overrated. I don’t think it’s a tumor.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: First year of medical school if you hear hoof beats you think “horses” not “zebras”.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Are you in first year of medical school? No. First of all, there’s nothing on the CAT scan. Second of all, if this is a horse then the kindly family doctor in Trenton makes the obvious diagnosis and it never gets near this office. Differential diagnosis, people: if it’s not a tumor what are the suspects? Why couldn’t she talk?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Aneurysm, stroke, or some other ischemic syndrome.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Get her a contrast MRI.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Creutzfeld-Jakob disease.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Mad cow?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mad zebra.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Wernickie's encephalopathy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, blood thiamine level was normal.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Lab in Trenton could have screwed up the blood test. I assume it’s a corollary if people lie, that people screw up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Re-draw the blood tests. And get her scheduled for that contrast MRI ASAP. Let’s find out what kind of zebra we’re dealing with here.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I was expecting you in my office 20 minutes ago.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Really? Well, that’s odd, because I had no intention of being in your office 20 minutes ago.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You think we have nothing to talk about?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, just that I can’t think of anything that I’d be interested in.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I sign your paychecks.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I have tenure. Are you going to grab my cane now, stop me from leaving?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That would be juvenile.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I can still fire you if you’re not doing your job.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m here from 9 to 5.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Your billings are practically nonexistent.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Rough year.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You ignore requests for consults.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I call back. Sometimes I misdial.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re 6 years behind on your obligation to this clinic.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: See, I was right, this doesn’t interest me.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: 6 years, times 3 weeks; you owe me better than 4 months.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s 5:00. I’m going home.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: To what?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nice.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Look, Dr. House, the only reason that I don’t fire you is because your reputation still worth something to this hospital.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Excellent, we have a point of agreement. You aren’t going to fire me.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Your reputation won’t last up if you don’t do your job. The clinic is part of your job. I want you to do your job.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, like the philosopher Jagger once said, “You can’t always get what you want.”

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: You’re not my doctor. Are you Dr. House?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Thankfully no. I’m Dr. Chase.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Dr. House is the head of diagnostic medicine. He’s very busy, but he has taken a keen interest in your case.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We inject gadolinium into a vein. It distributes itself throughout your brain and acts as a contrast material for the magnetic resonance imagery.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Basically, whatever’s in your head, lights up like a Christmas tree.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It might make you feel a little light-headed.

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Dr. Cameron. I’m sorry I have to stop you, there’s a problem.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You pulled my authorization.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Yes, why are you yelling?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No MRIs, no imaging studies, no labs.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You also can’t make long distance phone calls.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If you’re gonna fire me at least have the guts to face me.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Or photocopies; you’re still yelling.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m ANGRY! You’re risking a patient’s life.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I assume those are two separate points.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You showed me disrespect, you embarrassed me and as long as I’m still work here you have…

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Is your yelling designed to scare me because I’m not sure what I’m supposed to be scared of. More yelling? That’s not scary. That you’re gonna hurt me? That’s scary, but I’m pretty sure I can outrun ya.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Oh, I looked into that philosopher you quoted, Jagger, and you’re right, “You can’t always get what you want,” but as it turns out “if you try sometimes you get what you need.”

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, because you want me to treat patients, you aren’t letting me treat patients.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I need you to do your job.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do the MRI, she folded. I’ve gotta do four hours a week in this clinic until I make up the time I’ve missed. 2054. I’ll be caught up in 2054. You better love this cousin a whole lot.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: All right Rebecca, we know you may feel a little claustrophobic in there, but we need you to remain still.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Ok, we’re gonna begin.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: I don’t feel so good.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s all right. Just try to relax.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Rebecca? Rebecca? Rebecca! Get her out of there.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Ah she probably fell asleep; she’s exhausted.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She was claustrophobic 30 seconds ago, she’s not sleeping. We gotta get her out of there!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’ll just be another minute.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She’s having an allergic reaction to gadolinium. She’ll be dead in two minutes.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hold her neck.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Oh, she’s ashen.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’s not breathing. Epi point five.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Come on, I can’t ventilate.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Too much edema, where’s the surgical airway kit?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yep, coming.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Good call.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’ll get that tube out of your throat later today.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Just get some rest for now.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Told you, can’t trust people.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She probably knew she was allergic to gadolinium, figured it was an easy way to get someone to cut a hole in her throat.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can’t get a picture, gonna have to get a thousand words.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You actually want me to talk to the patient? Get a history?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We need to know if there’s some genetic or environmental causes triggering an inflammatory response.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I thought everybody lied?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Truth begins in lies. Think about it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That doesn’t mean anything,does it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: 12:52 PM Dr. House checks in, please write that down. Do you have cable TV here somewhere? General Hospital starts in 8 minutes.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No TV, but we’ve got patients.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can’t you give out the aspirin yourself? I’ll do paperwork.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I made sure your first case was an interesting one.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cough just won’t go away, runny nose looks a funny color.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Patient admitted complaining of back spasms.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I think I read about something like that in the New England Journal of Medicine.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Patient is orange.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The color?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No, the fruit.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You mean yellow; it’s jaundice.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I mean orange.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, how orange?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Exam room 1.

utterance.speaker: Orange Guy
utterance.content: I was playing golf and my cleat got stuck. I mean, it hurt a little but I kept playing. The next morning I could barely stand up. Well, you’re smiling so I take it that means this isn’t serious.

utterance.speaker: Orange Guy
utterance.content: What’s that? What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Painkillers.

utterance.speaker: Orange Guy
utterance.content: Oh, for you, for your leg.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, ‘cause they’re yummy. You want one? It’ll make your back feel better.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Unfortunately, you have a deeper problem. Your wife is having an affair.

utterance.speaker: Orange Guy
utterance.content: What?!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re orange, you moron! It’s one thing for you not to notice, but if your wife hasn’t picked up on the fact that her husband has changed color, she’s just not paying attention. By the way, do you consume just a ridiculous amount of carrots and mega-dose vitamins?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The carrots turn you yellow, the niacin turns you red. Get some finger-paints and do the math. And get a good lawyer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Deep breath.

utterance.speaker: Little boy
utterance.content: It’s cold.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Has he been using his inhaler?

utterance.speaker: Mother
utterance.content: Not in the past few days. He’s, um, only ten. I worry about children taking such strong medicine so frequently.

utterance.speaker: Little boy
utterance.content: What happened to your leg?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your doctor probably was concerned about the strength of the medicine, too. She probably weighed that danger against the danger of not breathing. Oxygen is so important during those prepubescent years, don’t you think? Ok, I’m gonna assume that no body’s ever told you what asthma is, or if they have, you had other things on your mind. A stimulant triggers cells in your child’s airways to release substances that inflame the air passages and cause them to contract. Mucus production increases, cell-lining starts to shed. But the steroids, the steroids…stop the inflammation. The more often this happens…

utterance.speaker: Mother
utterance.content: What? “The more often this happens…”what?”

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Forget it. If you don’t trust steroids, you shouldn’t trust doctors.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: My mother passed away three years ago. She had a heart attack, and my father broke his back doing construction.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s House, it’s urgent. I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You couldn’t have knocked?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Steroids. Give her steroids, high doses of prednisone.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’re looking for support for a diagnosis of cerebral vasculitus.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Inflammation of the blood vessels in the brain is awfully rare. Especially for someone her age.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So is a tumor. Her SED rate was elevated.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Mildly.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: That could mean anything, or nothing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, I know. I have no reason to think that it’s vasculitus except that it could be.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You can’t diagnose that without a biopsy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes, we can, we treat it. If she gets better we know that we’re right.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: And if we’re wrong?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We learn something else.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Why steroids?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Just part of your treatment. You haven’t had many visitors. No boyfriend?

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Three dates. I wouldn’t have stood by him if her were vomiting all day.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Well, what abut work? You must have friends from work.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Pretty much everybody I like is 5 years old. A nurse said you’re stopping my radiation.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’re just trying some alternative medications. So, where’s your family from then?

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Steroids aren’t an alternative to radiation.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The tests weren’t really conclusive.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We’re treating you for vasculitus, it’s the inflammation of blood vessels in the brain.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: It’s not a tumor? I don’t have a tumor?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You should have told her the truth. It’s a long shot guess.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Thank you. If House is right, no harm, if he’s wrong we’ve given a dying woman a couple days hope.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: False hope.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: If there was any other type available I would have given her that.

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: Why are you smelling Billy’s pants?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’m not.

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: Looked like you were.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I was smelling the floor.

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: Oh.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Do you have any pets in this class?

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: No, but we used to have a gerbil, but Carly L. dropped a book on it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Careless.

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: Do you need to smell it?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, I’m smelling for mold. I don’t need to smell it.

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: You can smell our parrot.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You said you didn’t have any pets in this class.

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: A parrot is a bird.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Parrots are the primary source of psitticosis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s not the parrot.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Psitticosis can lead to nerve problems and neurological complications.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How many kids were there in the class?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How many are home sick?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: None, but…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: None, but you think that 5 year olds are more serious about bird hygiene than their teacher. You’ve been through her home?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She lives in Trenton. I can go up to her room tomorrow morning and ask her for the key.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Would the police call for permission before dropping by to check out a crime scene?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s not a crime scene.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Far as I know she’s running a Meth Lab out of her basement.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’s a kindergarten teacher!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And if I was a Kindergarten student I would trust her implicitly. Ok, I’ll give you a for instance. The lady back there, who made your egg-salad sandwich. Her eyes look glassy, did you notice that? Now hospital policy is to stay home if you’re sick, but if you’re making $8.00 an hour, then ya kinda need the $8.00 an hour right? The sign in the bathroom says that employees must wash after using the facilities, but I figure that somebody who wipes snot on a sleeve isn’t hyper concerned about sanitary conditions. So what do ya think? Should I trust her? I want you to check the patient’s home for contaminants, garbage, medication…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Whoa, oh, I can’t just break into someone’s house.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Isn’t that how you got into the Felker’s home? Yeah, I know, court records are sealed, you were 16, it was a stupid mistake, but your old gym teacher has a big mouth. You should write a thank you note.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I should thank him?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, I needed somebody around here with street smarts. Ok? Knows when you’re being conned, knows how to con.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I should sue you!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m pretty sure you can’t sue somebody for wrongful hiring.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: But I’m pretty sure I can sue if you fire me for not breaking into some lady’s house.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m doing research. People are fascinating aren’t they?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Why are you giving Adler steroids?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, she’s my patient that’s what you do with patients. You give them medicine.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You don’t prescribe medicine based on guesses. At least we don’t since Tuskeegee and Mengele.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re comparing me to a Nazi? Nice.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m stopping the treatment.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s my patient.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s my hospital.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I did not get her sick, she is not an experiment, I have a legitimate theory about what’s wrong with her.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: With no proof.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There’s never any proof. 5 different doctors come up with 5 different diagnoses based on the same evidence.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You don’t have any evidence. And nobody knows anything huh? Then how is it that you always assume you’re right?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t, I just find it hard to operate on the opposite assumption. And why are you so afraid of making a mistake?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Because I’m a doctor. Because when we make mistakes people die.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Come on.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: People used to have more respect for cripples you know! They didn’t really.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Much better, thanks. Are you Dr. House? I thought he was a he, but…?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No. Don’t eat too much too fast.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Thank him for me.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Should I discontinue the treatment, boss?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You got lucky.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cool, huh?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Ok, once again.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Good.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Am I ever gonna meet Dr. House?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, you might run into him at the movies or on the bus.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Is he a good man?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He’s a good doctor.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Can you be one without the other? Don’t you have to care about people?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Caring’s a good motivator. He’s found something else. Feel this?

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: umhmm

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How about this?

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: umhmm

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Ok squeeze. Harder. All right.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: He’s your friend, huh?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Does he care about you?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I think so.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: You don’t know?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: As Dr. House likes to say, “Everybody lies.”

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: It’s not what people say, it’s what they do.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yes, he cares about me.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: I can’t see. I can’t see.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: A little help in here!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Your chest will be sore for a while. We needed to shock you to get your heart going. Ok. Can you arrange these to tell a story?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She couldn’t put them in order.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Could the damage have been caused by a lack of oxygen during her seizure?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, I gave her the same test 5 minutes later and she did just fine. The altered mental status is intermittent, just like the verbal skills.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: So, what now?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Given the latest symptoms it’s clearly growing deeper into the brain stem. Soon she won’t be able to walk, she’ll go blind permanently, and then the respiratory center will fail.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How long do we have?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If it’s a tumor we’re talking a month, maybe two, if it’s infectious a few weeks, if it’s vascular that’ll probably be fastest of all, maybe a week.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We’re gonna stop all treatment.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I still think it’s a tumor. I think we should go back to the radiation.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She didn’t respond to the radiation.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, maybe we didn’t see the effects until we started steroids.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, it’s not a tumor. The steroids did something, I just don’t know what.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So we’re just gonna do nothing? We’re just gonna watch her die?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, we’re gonna watch her die. Specifically we’re gonna watch how fast she’s dying. You just told us, each diagnosis has its own timeframe. When we see how fast it’s killing her we’ll know what it is.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: And by then maybe there’s nothing we can do about it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There’s go to be something we can do, something better than watching her die.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, I got nothing. How ‘bout you?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Bastard. Oh, Cameron, I need you for a couple of hours.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What’s up?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: When you break into someone’s house; it’s always better to have a white chick with you.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Adler’s house? Why don’t we just ask her for a key?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: For all we know she could be running a meth lab out of her basement.

utterance.speaker: Guy
utterance.content: I’m tired a lot.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Any other reason you think you may have Chronic Fatigue Syndrome?

utterance.speaker: Guy
utterance.content: It’s kinda the definition isn’t it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s kinda the definition of getting older.

utterance.speaker: Guy
utterance.content: I had a couple headaches last month, mild fever, sometimes I can’t sleep, and I have trouble concentrating.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Apparently not while researching this stuff on the internet.

utterance.speaker: Guy
utterance.content: I was thinking it also might be fibromyalgia.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Excellent diagnosis !

utterance.speaker: Guy
utterance.content: Is there anything for that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ya know, I think there just might be.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need 36 Vicodin, and change for a dollar.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Exam room 2.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House doesn’t believe in pretense. Figures life’s too short and too painful. So he just says what he thinks.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Nothing interesting in the garbage. “I say what I think” is just another way of saying “I’m an ass.”

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Well, if you wanted to be judged on your medical prowess only, maybe you shouldn’t have broken into someone’s home.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I was 16! Don’t know about ticks, but her dog’s definitely got fleas.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I managed to make it to 17 without a criminal record.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah? Well you obviously didn’t grow up in my neighborhood.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: That’s right. You stole a loaf of bread to feed your starving family right? You always eat during break-ins?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Am I supposed to respect their food more than I respect their DVD players? You want some?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You gonna go hungry until she dies?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You know what, after centuries of oppression, decades of civil rights marches, and more significantly living like a monk, never getting less than a 4.0 GPA, you don’t think it’s kind of disgusting I get one of the top jobs in the country because I’m a delinquent? We’ll eat, then we’ll tear up the carpet.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You went to Hopkins right?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yep.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: So, you went to a better school than I did, got better grades than I did.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So how’d you get the job? Did you stab a guy in a bar fight?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Nothing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s not a tumor; she’s getting worse too fast. She can’t stand up.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No toxins, no medication?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Nothing that would explain these symptoms.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Family history of neurological problems?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not that I could tell from her underwear drawer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You said nothing that would explain these symptoms. What did you find that doesn’t explain these symptoms?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Dr. Wilson convinced you to treat this patient under false pretenses. Adler’s not his cousin.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: That’s ridiculous. You can ask her yourself. Can we get back to…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’s not Jewish!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Rachel Adler’s not Jewish?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I had ham at her apartment!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Dr. Foreman, a lot of Jews have non-Jewish relatives, and most of us don’t keep kosher. I can see getting through high school without learning a thing about Jews, but medical school…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Ok, maybe she’s Jewish, but she’s definitely not your cousin.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Really? This guy’s…he…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You don’t even know her name! You called her Rachel; her name is Rebecca!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yes, yes, her name is Rebecca. I call her Rachel.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You idiot!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hey…listen…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not you, him! You said you didn’t find anything.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Everything I found was in

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You found ham.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Where there’s ham there’s pork, where there’s pork there’s neurocysticercosis.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Tapeworm?! You think she’s got a worm in her brain?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It fits. Could have been living there for years, it never occurred to me

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Millions of people eat ham every day. It’s quite a leap to think that she’s got a tapeworm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: OK, Mr. Neurologist. What happens when you give steroids to a person who has a tapeworm?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: They, they get a little better and then they get worse.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Just like Rebecca Adler did.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: In a typical case if you don’t cook pork well enough you ingest live tapeworm larvae. They got these little hooks they grab onto your bowel, they live, they grow up, they reproduce.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Reproduce? There’s only got one lesion, and it’s nowhere near her bowel.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s because this is not a typical case. Tapeworm can produce 20 to 30,000 eggs a day. Guess where they go.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Out.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not all of them. Unlike the larvae, the egg can pass right through the walls of the intestines and into the blood stream. And where does the blood stream go?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Everywhere.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: As long as it’s healthy the immune system doesn’t even know it’s there. The worm builds a wall, uses secretions to shut down the body’s immune response and control fluid flow. It’s really kinda beautiful.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: As long as it’s healthy, so what do we do? Call a vet and nurse the little guy back to health?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s too late for that. It’s dying, and as it dies this parasite loses the ability to control of the host’s defenses. The immune system wakes up and attacks the worm and everything starts to swell, and that is very bad for the brain.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It could still be a hundred other things. The eosinophil count was normal.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s only abnormal in 30% of cases.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Proving nothing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, no, no, no, you see, it fits, it’s perfect! It explains everything.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: But it proves nothing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I can prove it by treating it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, you can’t. I was just with her, she doesn’t want any more treatments, she doesn’t want any more experiments, she wants to go home and die.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Will you excuse us, please?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m Dr. House.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: It’s good to meet you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re being an idiot. Ahem. You have a tapeworm in your brain, it’s not pleasant, but if we don’t do anything you’ll be dead by the weekend.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Have you actually seen the worm?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When you’re all better I’ll show you my diplomas.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: You were sure I had vasculitus too. Now I can’t walk and I’m wearing a

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m not talking about a treatment; I’m talking about a cure. But because I might be wrong, you want to die.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: What made you a cripple?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I had an infarction.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: A heart attack?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s what happens when the blood flow is obstructed. If it’s in the heart it’s a heart attack. If it’s in the lungs it’s a pulmonary embolism. If it’s in the brain it’s a stroke. I had it in my thigh muscles.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Wasn’t there something they could do?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There was plenty they could do, if they made the right diagnosis, but the only symptom was pain. Not may people get to experience muscle death.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Did you think you were dying?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I hoped I was dying.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: So you hide in your office, refuse to see patients because you don’t like the way people look at you. You feel cheated by life so now you’re gonna get even with the world. You want me to fight this. Why? What makes you think I’m so much better than you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When you’re scared, you’ll turn into me.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: I just want to die with a little dignity.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There’s no such thing! Our bodies break down, sometimes when we’re 90, sometimes before we’re even born, but it always happens and there’s never any dignity in it. I don’t care if you can walk, see, wipe your own ass. It’s always ugly, always. You can live with dignity, we can’t die with it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No treatment.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Maybe we can get a court order, override her wishes. Claim she doesn’t have the capacity to make this decision.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But she does.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: But we could claim that the illness made her mentally incompetent.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Pretty common result.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That didn’t happen here.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He’s not gonna do it. She’s not just a file to him anymore. He respects her.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: So because you respect her, you’re going to let her die?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I solved the case, my work is done.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Patients always want proof, we’re not making cars here, we don’t give guarantees.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I think we can prove it’s a worm. It’s noninvasive, it’s safe. I’m not completely sure but…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, yeah, yeah what’s the damn idea?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Have you ever seen a worm under an x-ray, a regular old no contrast 100-year-old technology x-ray? They light up like shotgun pellets. Just like on a contrast MRI.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Which is the same thing as a CT scan, which we did, which proved nothing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Worm cysts is the same density as the cerebrospinal fluid, we’re not going to see anything in her head, but Chase is right, he’s right, we should x-ray her, but we don’t x-ray her brain, we x-ray her leg, worms love thigh muscle. If she’s got one in her head I guarantee you there’s one in her leg.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Hold still, Rebecca.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: This here is a worm larva.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: So, if it’s in my leg, it’s in my brain?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Are you looking for a guarantee? It’s there, probably been there 6 to 10 years.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Could I have more?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Probably. It’s good news.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: What do we do now?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Now we get you better. Albendazole.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Two pills?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yeah, every day for at least a month with a meal.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Two pills?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yeah, possible side effects include abdominal pain, nausea, headache, dizziness, fever, and hair loss. We’ll probably make you keep taking the pills even if you get every one of those.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Why did you hire me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does it matter?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Kinda hard to work for a guy who doesn’t respect you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Is that rhetorical?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, it just seems that way because you can’t think of an answer. Does it make a difference why I think I’m a jerk? The only thing that matters is what you think. Can you do the job?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You hired a black guy because he had a juvenile record.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, it wasn’t a racial thing, I didn’t see a black guy. I just saw a doctor…with a juvenile record. I hired Chase ‘cause his dad made a phone call. I hired you because you are extremely pretty.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You hired me to get into my pants?!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I can’t believe that that would shock you. It’s also not what I said. No, I hired you because you look good; it’s like having a nice piece of art in the lobby.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I was in the top of my class.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But not THE top.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I did an internship at the Mayo Clinic.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes, you were a very good applicant.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: But not the best?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Would that upset you, really, to think that you were hired because of some genetic gift of beauty not some genetic gift of intelligence?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I worked very hard to get where I am.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But you didn’t have to. People choose the paths that gain them the greatest rewards for the least amount of effort. That’s a law of nature, and you defied it. That’s why I hired you. You could have married rich, could have been a model, you could have just shown up and people would have given you stuff. Lots of stuff, but you didn’t, you worked your stunning little ass off.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Am I supposed to be flattered?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Gorgeous women do not go to medical school. Unless they’re as damaged as they are beautiful. Were you abused by a family member?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sexually assaulted?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But you are damaged, aren’t you?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I have to go.

utterance.speaker: Orange guy
utterance.content: I followed her. I couldn’t stop thinking about what that doctor said.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I told you not to listen to him, he’s an idiot.

utterance.speaker: Orange guy
utterance.content: I was ORANGE.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I don’t want to know what you found out.

utterance.speaker: Orange guy
utterance.content: You don’t care?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m your doctor, you’ve been good to me and good to this hospital, of course I care, but I don’t see how this conversation can end well for me. Either your wife is having an affair, or she’s not having an affair and you have come here because you rightly think I should fire him, but I can’t even if it cost me your money, the son of a bitch is the best doctor we have.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Feeling any better?

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: I can’t complain.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: As you know the hospital has certain rules, and as you also know we tend to ignore them, but I think this one’s gonna be a little obvious unless we get your help.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: If anyone asks, you have 11 daughters and 5 sons.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Hi, you guys!

utterance.speaker: Class
utterance.content: Hi!

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Come here!

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: It’s so good to see you guys! I missed you! Is this for me?

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Oh, I love you guys. I wanted to thank Dr. House, but he never visited again.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He cured you, you didn’t cure him.

utterance.speaker: Rebecca
utterance.content: Ok, I want a hug and a kiss from every single one of you. Get up here right now!

utterance.speaker: Male Dr on mini TV
utterance.content: Hold on.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You said she was your cousin. Why would you lie?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It got you to take the case.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You lied to a friend to save a stranger, you don’t think that’s screwed up?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’ve never lied to me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I NEVER lie.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, really.

utterance.speaker: Male Dr on mini TV
utterance.content: Why do we do this?

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Dr. House? You have a patient.

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: He says he needs a refill.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Got change for a dollar?

utterance.speaker: Singing
utterance.content: “No, you can’t always get what you want.” “You can’t always get what you want.”
